summary: This document is an email chain from April 2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel and an FBI CART Coordinator regarding significant logistical and technical problems in processing and reviewing digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The correspondence details issues with tracking seized devices, linking emails to attachments, and loading data for review, highlighting challenges in the post-seizure evidence management phase of the investigation.

persons.name: Rozier, Christopher
persons.context: Mentioned as a recipient (Cc) on an email regarding the Epstein search warrant documents, indicating involvement in the evidence review process.

events.title: 2007 Property Search
events.description: Reference to a July 2007 search on one of Jeffrey Epstein's properties, during which 9 IDE hard drives were seized (later found to be 3 copies of 3 drives).

events.title: Evidence Processing and Transfer Issues
events.description: Ongoing correspondence over two months detailing significant problems in receiving, tracking, and reviewing over 1 million documents and digital media seized from Epstein's New York and Virgin Islands properties. Issues include inability to link emails to attachments, mismatched load files, and lack of a clear inventory.

locations: Virgin Islands (referring to Epstein's island property)
keyFacts: Over 1 million documents were received from seized devices, but reviewers had no way to link emails to their attachments (e.g., a reference to 'attached flight records' could not be connected to the actual records).
Technical failures included load files that did not match native files, making many large files 'completely invisible' to the review team and creating a major production problem for defense counsel.

Seized items included approximately 40+ digital storage devices from a New York mansion and more than 25 devices from the Virgin Islands, including servers, with many items (like Macs) still pending processing.

The correspondence reveals significant post-seizure evidence management challenges, including a lack of a basic inventory to track which devices had been processed and what data had been transferred, described as potentially 'a total disaster' for the review.
